moves.1. e4: e4. Centre opening - lets the Bishop and Queen out.
moves.1... c5: c5. The Sicilian Defense, which is one of the most commonly played openings in the world.
moves.2. Nf3: Nf3. The normal line of the Sicilian.
moves.2... e6: e6, deviating from the main line. This is supposed to strengthen d5 and also let the Bishop and Queen come out when needed.
moves.3. d4: d4, letting the dark-squared Bishop come out and also not blocking in the light squared Bishop.
moves.3... cxd4: Exchange of the pawns, letting White have a N on d4.
moves.4... Nc6: Developing a Knight. If NxN, White will have swapped off the only developed piece and after bxN Black can push into the centre with d5 and develop quickly on the queenside.
moves.5. Nc3: Defending the e pawn and developing a piece.
moves.5... a6: Protects against N or B to b5.
moves.6. Be3: Defending the Knight and developing a piece.
moves.6... d5: An attempt to go through the middle with an attack.
moves.7. exd5: Swaps off the pawn, as I preferred this line to not taking the pawn: for example ...dxe4 Nxe4 leaves two knights in the centre easily attacked.
moves.8. Be2: Develops the Bishop - ready to castle. Notice Black has one piece developed and White has 4.
moves.8... Be6: Black now has 2 pieces developed. Both people carry on developing in the next few moves.
moves.9. O-O Nf6 10. Re1 Bb4 11. Nxc6: Nxc6 lets the B come back to defend the N; if this move is not played first the Knight on d4 drops.
moves.11... bxc6 12. Bd2 c5 13. a3 Bxc3 14. Bx: In this position Black is more forward and has his pieces developed well - White has the slight advantage in development due to the Rook on e1.
moves.15... O-O 16. Bf3: The Bishop is now on a better diagonal; the Rook is on a better file.
moves.16... Rb8: So Black does not lose a tempo.
moves.17. b3 Qc7: Qc7 - this seems not to do much; it attacks the h2 square but now the Q and R are in a diagonal line...
moves.18... Ng4: Threatening h2, but White can now swap off...
moves.20... Qc6: Moves the Queen to a safe place.
moves.21. Bxb8 Rxb8 22. Qf4: Forking the Rook and Bishop, meaning Black has to move his Queen back.
moves.22... Qc8 23. Re5: White takes the initiative, threatening Rxc5, winning a pawn (if QxR, QxR , Qf8 Qf8 and Whte will win).
moves.23... Be6 24. Rxc5: Threatening the Queen, and winning a pawn.
moves.24... Qd8: Black does not want to swap off - he is losing and tries to keep his pieces on the board.
moves.25. h3: Prevents mate. Black should do the same; many of the tricks are to do with mate.
moves.25... Qb6: Does not threaten anything; QxR QxR Qf8 and White will win.
moves.27. Rxd4: White does not bother to defend it! Another pawn is won. If Black takes the Rook on c5, RxR  Qf8 Rxf8  Kxf8 and White is up by a long way.
moves.29. Rc8+: Rc8 ! The discovered attack on the Queen makes Black resign.

gameName: Pins, Back Rankers and Poisoned Rooks
